awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: ELSI-Infrastructure for Scalable Electronic Structure Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Predictive, so-called ab initio electronic structure calculations, particularly those based on the Kohn-Sham density functional theory (DFT) are now a widely used scientific workhorse with applications in virtually all sciences, and increasingly in engineering and industry. In materials science, they enable the computational ("in silico") design of new materials with improved properties. In biological or pharmacological research, they provide molecular-level insights into the function of macromolecules or drugs. In the search for new energy solutions, they give molecular-level insights into new solar cell designs, catalytic processes, and many others. A key bottleneck in many applications and calculations is the "cubic scaling wall" of the so-called Kohn-Sham eigenvalue problem with system size (i.e., the effort increases by a factor of 1,000 if the model size increases by a factor of 10). This project will establish an open source software infrastructure "ELSI" that offers a common, practical interface to initially three complementary solution strategies to alleviate or overcome the difficulty associated with solving the Kohn-Sham eigenvalue problem. ELSI will enable a broad range of end user communities, centered around different codes with, often, unique features that tie a specialized group of scientists to that particular solution, to easily incorporate state-of-the-art solution strategies for a key problem they all share. By providing these effective, accessible solution strategies, we will open up major areas for electronic structure theory where DFT based predictive methodologies are not applicable today. This will in turn open doors for new development in materials science, chemistry, and all related areas. Commitments to support ELSI exist from some of the most important electronic structure developer communities, as well as from industry and government leaders in high-performance computing. Thus, we will create a strong U.S. based infrastructure that leverages the large user and developer base from a globally active community developing DFT methods for materials research.

ELSI will support and enhance three state-of-the-art approaches, each best suited for a specific problem range: (i) The ELPA (EigensoLvers for Petascale Applications) library, a leading library for efficient, massively parallel solution of eigenvalue problems (for small- and mid-sized problems up to several 1,000s of atoms), (ii) the OMM (Orbital Minimization Method) in a recent re-implementation, which circumvents the eigenvalue problem by focusing on a reduced, auxiliary problem (for systems in the several 1,000s of atoms range), and (iii) the PEXSI (Pole EXpansion and Selective Inversion) library, a proven reduced scaling (at most quadratic scaling) solution for general systems (for problems with 1,000s of atoms and beyond). By establishing standardized interfaces in a style already familiar to many electronic structure developers, ELSI will enable production electronic structure codes that use it to significantly reduce the "scaling wall" of the eigenvalue problem. First, ELSI will help them make efficient use of the most powerful computational platforms available. The target platforms are current massively parallel computers and multicore architectures, GPU based systems and future manycore processors. Second, the project will make targeted methodological improvements to ELPA, OMM, and PEXSI, e.g., a more effective use of matrix sparsity towards very large systems. The focus on similar computational architectures and similar methodological enhancements will lead to significant cross-fertilization and synergy between these approaches.

por.por_cntn:
This project, called "ELSI - Infrastructure for Scalable Electronic Structure Theory", aimed at creating a software infrastructure that alleviates a key bottleneck in computational molecular and materials simulations using the framework of Kohn-Sham and so-called "generalized Kohn-Sham" density functional theory (DFT). Simply put, this simulation approach allows one to probe molecular and materials properties, e.g., to develop pharmaceuticals, semiconductors, energy technologies and a large variety of other applications, with high accuracy at affordable computational cost. Efficient use of high-performance computing resources continues to be an integral requirement. The overall approach is compellingly attractive and widely used in industry, in addition to academic research.

Among the key bottlenecks towards more powerful DFT simulations, the need to solve or circumvent the solution of a so-called eigenvalue problem by matrix algebra techniques can be the most time-consuming step. In short, the cost of an exact solution by standard techniques scales as the third power of N, if N is a measure of the simulation size. In this limit, a ten-fold larger simulation will increase the computational cost by factor of 1,000. From this simple estimate, it becomes clear that using large supercomputers can be advantageous or essential for certain outcomes and that methods development to reduce the cost is an important objective. However, the software engineering underneath such methods is not trivial - any given solution method, even if already in existence, must be connected to end user codes efficiently and must be updated to take advantage of new high-performance hardware generations.

The key outcome of the project is the establishment of an open-source software infrastructure, ELSI, that provides a simple, uniform interface to ten different solver libraries that either solve or circumvent the generalized Kohn-Sham eigenvalue problem (see Figure 1 for an illustration). This software infrastructure is now connected to five different electronic structure codes (the FHI-aims code, the DFTB+ code, the Siesta code, the DGDFT code and the NWChemEx code), all of which facilitate end user simulations of molecules and materials. Importantly, the ELSI infrastructure includes conversion formalisms for common storage formats of matrices used in the community (across parallel computers, these storage formats are frequently difficult to access). Additionally, detailed benchmarks of optimum solver choices for different application scenarios were published during the project, providing guidance for users.

Furthermore, the project provided key support to advance individual solvers, the most widely used ones being the massively parallel "ELPA" eigenvalue solver library, for which GPU support was implemented, and the "PEXSI" solver for very large systems, a core development of the group of collaborating PI Lin Lin at UC Berkeley.

Intellectual Merit: The project facilitated the creation of a software infrastructure "ELSI" that is now used in several large "end user" code projects, facilitating scientific simulations in materials science, chemistry, pharmacology and other areas. During the project, one major focus was the assessment of different solver strategies on existing and new high-performance platform. For practical simulations of DFT with high-precision densities, one insight is that the massively parallel ELPA solver provided the most competitive performance in a larger range of simulation scenarios than expected, i.e., for simulation sizes up to several thousand atoms and on computers up to several thousand CPU cores. Beyond these ranges, lower-scaling solvers such as PEXSI and the NTPoly density matrix solver have advantages, but themselves begin to compete with machine learning approaches trained by smaller direct simulation sizes. The open-source ELPA solver, especially its GPU port, also spurred alternative developments, such as NVidia's current cuSolver. ELPA, however, continues to offer support for more than just a single proprietary platform. Overall, the development of ELSI will remain an integral component of the electronic structure software ecosystem for the foreseeable future.

Broader Impact: The software developed in this project is now used by at least thousands of users, based on the PIs' estimates. Over the course of the project, community building and outreach to other, global communities (especially in Europe) have been a key focus of the project, leading to at least 13 workshops that were co-organized by ELSI PIs and that focused on bringing otherwise disparate software development communities together. Especially the interaction with the European "CECAM Electronic Structure Library" effort has been a focal point that bridged between otherwise separate developer communities from different projects. The project has also had both direct and indirect workforce development outcomes, with past graduate and postdoc researchers now placed in industry (e.g., Intel) as well as in academic settings in the U.S. and elsewhere. Finally, the software developments of the ELSI projects are now finding use in industrial settings, mediated through "end user" electronic structure codes. The PIs are aware of application use in the pharmaceutical industry, as well as in industries engaged in the creation of artificial intelligence solutions for molecular and materials science.
